Dear Katrina Edmon:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112 Staff Qualifications
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
Description following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff 1 is discussing sexual positions with Youth A and touching
him in sexual ways.
Investigation Interviews:
Parent 1 and Parent 2 were interviewed separately on the
telephone on 2/24/25. Both reported on 12/20/24, Youth A told
them a staff (unknown) says “inappropriate things” to him. Both
did not know the actual words that were spoken. Both reported
Youth A told them the staff made sexual gestures towards his own
(staff’s) penis. The gesture was not explained to them. Both
reported Youth A reported to them the staff would rub his lower
back in a sexual manner. This made Youth A uncomfortable. It
was reported to them that Youth A told a staff member (unknown)
about this behavior.
Parent 2 reported he told the allegations on 12/20/24 to Therapist
1 during a family visit on site. Parent 2 reported Therapist 1 stated
she would investigate the matter.
The following interviews were completed at the facility face to
face on 2/4/25 with the MDHHS Worker.
Youth A reported Staff 1 had him listen to music by Tamika
Fabulous. Youth A reported it had terms he did not understand in
it. One of those terms were “motion in the ocean.” Youth A
reported Staff 1 told him it had to do with a sexual position. Youth
A reported he didn’t understand the references the music was
making, and it made him uncomfortable. Youth A reported he has
never been touched by any staff member including Staff 1 in a
sexual manner.
Youth B and Youth C reported they have never heard Staff 1 play
music in the unit. Both reported they have not heard Staff 1 say
inappropriate sexual things to youth. Both reported they have
never seen Staff 1 touch any of the youth in an inappropriate way.
Administrator 1 reported she completed a Supervision for
Success document on 12/23/24 concerning Staff 1’s behavior
2

towards Youth A. It was concerning “horseplay.” Administrator 1
reported Staff 1 had turned down Youth A’s music due to it being
inappropriate music. Staff 1 had told her Youth A was playing
“Sexy Redd” and he made a comment about the music. Youth A
turned the music down and then Staff 1 attempted to “relate” to
the music being played by Youth A. Administrator 1 was unable to
verbalize what “relate” meant. Administrator 1 reported Staff 1 was
“horseplaying” with Youth A. Administrator 1 was unable to
verbalize what “horseplay” meant. Administrator 1 reported she
also discussed professional boundaries but was unable to
verbalize what aspect of professional boundaries was discussed.
Administrator 1 reported on 12/20/24, Therapist 1 told her about
an allegation concerning Youth A. It was stated Staff 1 had an
inappropriate conversation with Youth A and made him feel
uncomfortable. Therapist 1 had told her Staff 1 had given him a
pat on the middle of the back, and he felt uncomfortable.
Administrator 1 reported Therapist 1 did not state it was alleged as
a sexual touch, but did make Youth A feel uncomfortable.
Therapist 1 reported Parent 2 was on site for a family visit and
reported Youth A alleged Staff 1 had touched him in a sexually
inappropriate way on his back, which made Youth A
uncomfortable. She was also told Staff 1 did a dance move, where
he raised his arms above his head in a “V” and brought both arms
down at the same time to his private area. Therapist 1 reported to
Parent 2 that she would look into the matter. Therapist 1 reported
due to the nature of the allegations, she reported this to
Administrator 1 and Clinical Director 1. Therapist 1 reported two
weeks later Youth A recanted his allegation and stated Staff 1
accidently touched him.
The following interviews were completed on 2/19/25 at the
facility with the MDHHS Worker.
Staff 1 reported he has never had any issues with Youth A. Staff 1
reported Youth A can be violent and gets into fights with the other
youth in the unit. Staff 1 reported Youth A was listening to
inappropriate music while in the unit and he asked him to turn the
volume down. Staff 1 reported all the youth have MP3 players, but
they are able to connect it to the Bluetooth speaker or radio in
their room. Youth A will put his music on at night and raise the
volume so others can hear. Staff 1 reported any time he has
asked Youth A to turn the volume down he has complied. Staff 1
denied touching any youth inappropriately. Staff 1 reported he has
touched youth but not in an intentionally harming way or sexually
gratifying way. Staff 1 reported Youth A has never said to him,
3

“don’t touch me” or told him that he felt uncomfortable around him.
Staff 1 reported he does not play inappropriate music around the
youth, including Tamika Fabulous. Staff 1 reported he has never
said inappropriate sexual comments to any youth. Staff 1 reported
he has not danced inappropriately around children (in reference to
hand gestures towards his penis.) Staff 1 does not know what the
youth are allowed to listen to at the facility and has not reported
the music to any other staff or supervision. Staff 1 reported he had
a conversation with Administrator 1 about horseplay. Staff 1
reported this conversation was about “fake boxing.” Staff 1 denied
talking to Administrator 1 or any other supervisor concerning
touching Youth A inappropriately or inappropriate music.
Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 2 both reported they have worked
with Staff 1. Both denied they ever saw Staff 1 touch a youth
inappropriately. Both denied they have ever heard Staff 1 say
inappropriate things to youth. Both reported Staff 1 is a good staff
who engages in activities with the youth. Both reported they have
never had complaints from the youth regarding Staff 1.
Video Observation:
Video was not saved and therefore could not be reviewed. Email
on 1/23/25 from Administrator 1 to MDHHS Worker and myself
reported: “We reviewed the video, there was nothing seen of note.
Unfortunately, the video has no audio, and we retain videos for
thirty days…”
Documents Reviewed:
• Supervision for Success document: “It was brought to my
attention on 12/20/24 that Staff 1 was horseplaying with a
youth. It was discussed with Staff 1 via phone that staff are
not to at any time horseplay with youth within the program.
It was also discussed that staff are to always remain
professional and keep healthy boundaries within the
workplace…” This was dated 12/23/24 and completed by
Administrator 1.
• Staff schedule was reviewed and noted Staff 1 working with
Youth A’s unit on 12/15/24 and 12/18/24. These two dates
were the closest scheduled shifts to the allegations. Both
Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 2 were scheduled with Staff 1
on these dates.
• Staff 1’s personnel file was reviewed. All clearances and
training were up to date.
• There was not an incident report to review of the situation.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as Youth A and Staff 1 both
deny Staff 1 ever touched Youth A in a sexual manner. There is
4

no evidence to validate Staff 1 stating inappropriate sexual
comments towards Youth A. Staff 1 denied the allegations; Youth
B and Youth C reported they had never heard Staff 1 say anything
sexually inappropriate to any of the youth; and both Supervisor 1
and Supervisor 2 denied ever hearing Staff 1 make comments in
this manner.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4131 Compliance with child protection law;
Section development of plan required.
Description (1) The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to
assure compliance with the child protection law, 1975 PA 238,
MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The agency failed to report suspected child abuse and neglect as
outlined in the child protection law.
Investigation Interviews:
Parent 1 and Parent 2 were interviewed separately on the
telephone on 2/24/25. Both reported Youth A told them a staff
member says “inappropriate things” to him. Both did not know the
actual words spoken. Both reported Youth A told them the staff
made sexual gestures towards his own (staff’s) penis. The gesture
was not explained to them. Both reported Youth A reported to
them the staff would rub his lower back in a sexual manner. This
made Youth A uncomfortable. It was reported to them Youth A
told a staff member (unknown) about this behavior.
Parent 2 reported he told Therapist 1 the allegations Youth A
reported to him. Parent 2 reported Therapist 1 stated she would
look into the matter.
All interviews at the facility included the MDHHS Worker.
Therapist 1 was interviewed on 2/4/25 at the facility. Therapist 1
reported Parent 2 was on site for a family visit. Parent 2 reported
to her Youth A alleged Staff 1 had touched him in a sexually
inappropriate way on his back, which made Youth A
uncomfortable. She was also told Staff 1 did a dance move, where
he raised his arms above his head in a “V” and brought both arms
down to his private area at the same time. Therapist 1 reported to
Parent 2 that she would look into the matter. Therapist 1 reported
due to the nature of the allegations, she reported this to
Administrator 1 and Clinical Director 1. Therapist 1 described that
it was her role to notify her supervisors as a mandated reported.
5

Therapist 1 reported she felt this allegation raised to the level of
other parties to be involved. Therapist 1 reported she is to report
suspected child abuse and neglect when there is threat of
someone getting hurt or if someone is getting hurt sexually.
Therapist 1 reported she told Clinical Director 1 and Administrator
1 as her due diligence as a mandated reported. Therapist 1 did
not know if either called the allegations into centralized intake.
Therapist 1 was reinterviewed on the telephone on 2/24/25 and
she reported again that she told Administrator 1 and Clinical
Director 1 the allegations. Therapist 1 reported she did not write
an incident report for the allegations or case note the
conversations.
Clinical Director 1 was interviewed on 2/19/25 at the facility.
Clinical Director reported he had a conversation with Therapist 1
concerning Staff 1 and Youth A. He reported Therapist 1 stated
Youth A complained about a “look” he received from Staff 1. This
look made him feel uncomfortable. Clinical Director 1 reported he
does not remember Therapist 1 telling him the allegations were
concerning a touch alleged to be sexual. Clinical Director 1 was
asked what the mandated reporting policy says. He reported staff
are to tell him about any allegations and then he would make the
phone call to centralized intake. Clinical Director 1 reported the
staff would report anything that puts youth in harms way. This
could be unsafe mentally or physically.
Administrator 1 was interviewed on 2/4/25 at the facility.
Administrator 1 reported Therapist 1 gave her information that
Youth A made allegations against Staff 1. The allegations were
that Staff1 had an inappropriate conversation with Youth A.
Administrator 1 was unable to recall what the conversation was
about. She also was told Staff 1 gave Youth A a pat on the back
that made him feel uncomfortable because it was too low. The
location on the back was described as the middle. Administrator 1
reported the pat was not described as sexual to her.
Documents Reviewed:
• I reviewed the Reporting Policy:
The staff member receiving the report of actual or
suspected sexual abuse or rape must immediately call
Child Protective Services and report the incident and/or
allegation. Staff receiving the report of actual or suspected
abuse…must submit an Incident Report before the end of
their work shift…
• An incident report was requested for the allegations, but
there was not one completed.
6

• I reviewed Therapist 1’s training file. Therapist 1 received
training on Mandated Reporting on 9/25/24.
Analysis The agency is in violation of this rule. Therapist 1 received
information involving Youth A allegedly being touched sexually.
Therapist 1 reported she thought providing this information to
Administrator 1 and Clinical Director 1 would suffice as a
mandated reporter. The agency did not follow their incident report
writing policy.
Technical Assistance:
Based on interviews, there is some confusion on who is to report
suspected abuse and neglect as well as what is to be
documented. There was also a miscommunication or
misunderstanding of information from Therapist 1 to Clinical
Director 1 and Administrator 1. A training would be helpful to
discuss requirements of mandate reporting, including what is to be
reported, whom the information is to be shared with, and how to
report the information due to the serious nature of allegations.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
Description program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents'
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The agency does not have a policy or procedures concerning the
usage of technology which includes music. Because of this Youth
A was able to have and listen to music outside the treatment
milieu (trauma-focused).
Investigation Interviews:
All interviews at the facility include the MDHHS Worker.
Administrator 1 as interviewed on 2/4/25 at the facility.
Administrator 1 reported Youth A was listening to “Sexy Redd” in
the unit. Administrator 1 reported Staff 1 had turned down Youth
A’s music due to it being inappropriate music. Administrator 1
reported many youths will download inappropriate music when they
are at school or at the library. If staff discover the inappropriate
music, they will ask the youth to delete the music from their MP3
player. Administrator 1 was unsure if anyone deleted it from Youth
A’s MP3.
7

Staff 1 was interviewed on 2/4/25 at the facility. Staff 1 reported
Youth A listens to inappropriate music and he has asked him to
turn the volume down. Staff 1 reported the youth have MP3 players
but can also connect it to the Bluetooth speaker or radio in their
room. Youth A will put his music on at night and raise the volume.
Staff 1 reported any time he has asked Youth A to turn the volume
down he has complied. Staff 1 reported he does not know what
music the youth are allowed to listen to at the facility and has not
reported the music to any other staff or supervision.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed on 2/19/25 at the facility. Supervisor
1 reported the youth are not allowed to have inappropriate music
on their MP3 players. Supervisor 1 defined inappropriate as
profanity and explicit lyrics. Supervisor 1 reported the agency has
“kid friendly” internet at the facility to stop inappropriate
downloading. Supervisor 1 reported the units used to have just
radios in them, but the last two years youth have been given MP3
players, so it is harder to monitor music. Supervisor 1 reported
Youth A is explosive, and staff have to pick their battles with him. If
staff confront Youth A on his music, he will explode. Supervisor 1
reported Youth A tests limits and attempts to portray himself as the
victim in situations. Supervisor 1 reported the youth in the unit are
cognitively lower-functioning and the music exposes them to lyrics
they do not understand. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A listens to
“Sexy Redd.” Supervisor 1 reported the music Youth A listens to
would make one “blush.”
Supervisor 2 was interviewed on 2/19/25 at the facility. Supervisor
2 reported youth can listen to music. Supervisor 2 reported the
music is downloaded by the therapist. Supervisor 2 reported the
policy for music is no profanity or vulgarities. Supervisor 2 reported
that if the staff hear inappropriate music, then they are to turn the
music off, confiscate the MP3 and erase the music and report it to
the therapist.
Clinical Director 1 was interviewed on 2/19/25 at the facility. He
reported the therapist download music for the youth. He reported
the agency does not have a specific policy on music for youth.
Clinical Director 1 reported it is the youths’ “universal right” to be
able to listen to music. Clinical Director 1 reported the music could
be downloaded if it was the “clean version.” The clean version was
described as no profanity or anything explicit. Clinical Director 1
reported it has been brought to their attention that youth will
download music when at school or at the library. Clinical Director 1
8

reported if there was inappropriate music being played, they would
have the youth delete the song and then discuss it with them.
Parent 1 and Parent 2 were both interviewed via telephone on
2/24/25 and both reported they have blocks on the music that
Youth A is allowed to listen to. Both reported Youth A is not
allowed to listen to “Sexy Redd in their home.” Parent 2 reported
that music is a “disgrace.”
Worker 1 was interviewed via telephone on 2/24/25. Worker 1
reported Youth A was cognitively eight or nine years old. Worker 1
reported Youth A came into care with concerns on usage of
internet and YouTube. Worker 1 reported he likes to listen to
inappropriate music and was caught watching videos of “Sexy
Redd” in the hospital. The videos showed women with limited
clothing and smacking the backsides of each other. These videos
were taken from him. Worker 1 reported Therapist 1 downloads
Youth A’s music for him.
Youth A was interviewed on 2/4/25 at the facility. Youth A reported
he has music from “Sexy Redd” on his MP3. He stated two songs;
“Fat, Juicy, and Wet” and “Baby I love you”.
Therapist 1 was interviewed on 2/24/25 via telephone. Therapist 1
reported she downloads the music for Youth A. Therapist 1
reported Youth A is at a 11-12 cognitive functioning. Therapist 1
reported she has downloaded music from “Gorilla” and “Sexy
Redd.” Therapist 1 reported she does not listen to the entirety of
the lyrics when downloading the music. Therapist 1 reported she
makes sure the lyrics are the clean versions. Therapist 1 reported
this meant no profanity. Therapist 1 reported there is not a policy
concerning music.
Documents Reviewed:
• I requested policies and procedures concerning music. The
agency provided me with the following:
o Job Role Responsibilities policy: This policy states
that staff are to be “role models,” maintain
“professional boundaries,” and “provide proper
supervision so that the care, welfare, safety, and
security of the residents are ensured.” This policy did
not have procedures that outlined electronic devices.
o Supervision Policy: This policy discussed being able
to visually see youth and audibly hear youth.
9

o I requested a “recreation policy” and received the Off-
Ground policy. This policy did not pertain to policy
and procedures concerning electronic devices.
o Television, Movies, and Video Games Policy:
As part of the design of the therapeutic milieu,
consideration must be given to the influence that
television and movies has on the treatment of those
individuals within the milieu…All television shows,
movies, and video games must be monitored for their
content. Television shows, video games, and movies
that depict violence, violent images, sex,
consumption or usage of substances, and have
profanity or lewd language are prohibited. For young
people who are 12 years of age or older, they may be
permitted to watch PG-13 movies. Those movies
should be approved by the Assistant Cottage
Supervisor and should not contain any scenes
depicting sex or sexual violence.
• I reviewed Lyrics of “Sexy Redd” song, “Fat, Juicy, and
Wet.” I was unable to find lyrics for “Baby I love you.” The
lyrics included sexually explicit activities and lewd language.
• I reviewed the Program Statement: The treatment
philosophy of MCHS’ residential treatment program is based
on a trauma-focused, whole system approach to the
therapeutic milieu…one of the major goals is to provide
treatment that effectively meets the emotional, cognitive,
social and developmental needs for the youth in care.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance as it does not have a policy
or procedures pertaining to downloading music and monitoring it.
Staff 1, Supervisor 2, Supervisor 3, Clinical Director 1, and
Therapist 1 all had different procedures on downloading music
and monitoring it. Staff 1, Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 2 reported
the music as inappropriate, and Therapist 1 reported she
downloaded “Sexy Redd” and did not listen to all the lyrics. The
agency does have a policy pertaining to “Television, Movies, and
Video Games.” This policy, although not directly discussing music,
does speak to ensuring youth are safe guarded against “movies
that depict violence, violent images, sex, consumption or usage of
substances, and have profanity or lewd language are prohibited.
For young people who are 12 years of age or older, they may be
permitted to watch PG-13 movies.” The music downloaded onto
Youth A’s MP3 speak of sexual activities and lewd language. Both
are prohibited in visual and auditory electronics, as noted in policy
due to the treatment milieu (trauma-informed environment) and
influence they have.
10

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered for the agency to update their
current “Television, Movies, and Video Games Policy” or include a
new policy with procedures for music. The procedures for
downloading and monitoring will need to be outlined. The policy
should emphasize a trauma informed approach as outlined in the
program statement. Because there has not been a policy or
procedure for the downloading of the music, the agency will need
to evaluate what has been downloaded onto youth who do have
MP3 players and ensure the music is in agreement with their
Program Statement.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

SIR 2024C0001088SI; CAP approved 7/22/24
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
